title: Postoperative Surgical Site Infection
diagnosis_topic: Superficial and deep surgical site infection following abdominal surgery
setup_script: A 50-year-old man is postoperative day 7 after a sigmoid colectomy. He develops fever and redness around his midline incision. He complains of increasing incisional pain and foul-smelling drainage.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 122/78 mmHg, HR 104 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.5 C.
Erythema extending 3 cm from the wound edges, warmth, fluctuance in lower aspect with purulent drainage.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for fascial integrity
dynamic_flow.reply: Cough test shows intact fascia; no evisceration.
WBC 15 K/uL, CRP elevated; blood cultures obtained.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident opens the lower portion of incision for drainage
dynamic_flow.reply: Pus evacuated; wound probed and irrigated; culture sent.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident begins empiric IV antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Start coverage targeting skin flora and enteric organisms (cefazolin + metronidazole).
No deep abscess; fluid collection limited to subcutaneous space.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays opening the wound
dynamic_flow.reply: Infection may extend to fascia causing dehiscence or sepsis.
Negative pressure wound therapy considered to promote healing.
Glycemic control, smoking cessation, adequate nutrition addressed.
Instruct on wound care, signs of worsening infection and follow-up visits.
Perioperative antibiotics, sterile technique and normothermia reduce infection risk.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of postoperative surgical site infection
Assessment of fascial integrity and need for emergent intervention
Appropriate drainage, culture and antibiotic therapy
Imaging to evaluate for deep abscess or anastomotic leak
Optimization of patient factors and wound care to promote healing
